title: 109_s3584
content: The "Federal Supervisor Training Act of 2006" requires mandatory training programs for supervisors. The "Federal Supervisor Training Act of 2006" mandates training programs for supervisors, amending Section 4121 of title 5, United States Code to define a supervisor and establish operating standards for consultation. The "Federal Supervisor Training Act of 2006" mandates interactive instructor-based training for supervisors on various actions and strategies, including goal-setting, progress communication, performance appraisals, mentoring, and motivation of employees. The "Federal Supervisor Training Act of 2006" requires training for supervisors on mentoring, motivating employees, managing unacceptable performance, and carrying out supervisor duties. Additionally, the training covers prohibited personnel practices and processes for enforcing employee rights. The Federal Supervisor Training Act of 2006 mandates training for supervisors on mentoring, motivating employees, managing performance, and enforcing employee rights. New supervisors must complete a mentoring program within one year of appointment. The Federal Supervisor Training Act of 2006 requires supervisors to complete training programs every 3 years, with credit given for previous similar training. The Office of Personnel Management will prescribe regulations for agency compliance. The Office of Personnel Management must create regulations within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The amendments will take effect 180 days after the Act's enactment and apply to individuals appointed as supervisors. Each individual employed as a supervisor must complete programs under section 4121(b)(2) of title 5, United States Code within 3 years of the effective date of the Act. Each supervisor must complete programs within 3 years of the Act's effective date and every 3 years thereafter. SEC. 3. MANAGEMENT COMPETENCY STANDARDS. Section 4305 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to include management competency standards for supervisors defined under section 7103(a)(10) and (11), as well as other employees designated by the Office of Personnel Management. The Office of Personnel Management will provide guidance to agencies on the standards supervisors are expected to meet. Each agency is required to develop standards for assessing supervisor performance, taking into account guidance from the Office of Personnel Management. They must also evaluate supervisors' capacity to meet the OPM's guidance. Each agency must develop standards for assessing supervisor performance and implement a supervisor training program to address identified issues. Agencies are required to submit progress reports annually to the Office of Personnel Management. Technical amendments are made to the table of sections for chapter 43 of title 5, United States Code. Technical amendments are made to the table of sections for chapter 43 of title 5, United States Code, including the amendment of management competency standards and regulations. Section 4304(b)(3) is updated to reference section 4306 instead of 4305.
